Mini 1394

Moderator: Melmond
Backup Mod: pappums rat
Reviewers: Vi, Mykonian, Regfan




The Rules (stolen from pappums rat):

Rule 1: Do not talk about this game outside of this thread unless your PM says you can.
Rule 2: Do not quote PM's from the mod or text from your QT if you have one.
Rule 3: Do not use invisible text or hidden code.
Rule 4: Do not delete or edit previous posts.
Rule 5: Do not make personal attacks against other players.
Rule 6: Please bold your votes or use tags, as unbolded votes will not count.
Rule 7: When a player has a majority of people voting for them, they will be lynched. Voting for no lynch for the day is also possible. If no one gains a majority during a day, there will be no lynch for the day, and night will begin.
Rule 8: Days will last a maximum of 2 weeks, but can be shorter if a lynch or no lynch is reached before the deadline. Extensions are possible, but unlikely. Nights will last 48 hours. If I do not receive a night action within that 48 hours, it will not count.
Rule 9: If you die, you are allowed to make one 'bah' post that has no content in it, but after that no talking.
Rule 10: If you are going to be away from the game for an extended period of time, please declare yourself V/LA in thread, and say how long you expect to be gone. If a player does not declare V/LA and they do not post for 48 hours, they will be prodded. They then have 24 hours to pick up their prod and start posting or they will be replaced out. If a person has been prodded twice and fails to post for 48 hours, instead of receiving another prod they will be replaced out.
Rule 11: If you need to leave the game, please contact me via PM or say so in bold in the thread. It will be much appreciated over just flaking from the game.
Rule 12: All roles will be decided by using random.org.
Rule 13: Play to your win condition.
Rule 14: I reserve the right to change the rules at any time if I feel it is necessary.
Rule 15: If you break any of the rules, it will be my decision whether you are warned, replaced, or modkilled.

Here is a sample Vanilla Townie role PM:
Hello, [player], you are a Vanilla Townie. You have no abilities other than your voice and your vote.
You win when all threats to the town have been eliminated and at least one member of the town is still alive. If you have any questions about your role or about the game in general, please feel free to PM me and I will answer them if I can.

Me saying that he's town really doesn't mean anything at all - it could be a slight suspicion, it could be the preamble to me claiming a hilarious daycop result. But then you go and say that i "seem to know something pretty definitive."

There are a few problems with that. First of all, you're accusing me without accusing me - that is, taking an accusatory tone without actually directly accusing me. Second, you use the word "seems," which is hedging around the issue and making your position even less clear. Third, you're implying that my calling someone town means that i know something about him. But really, the big problem is that you're taking an accusatory tone without taking an explicit stance, which is scummy.

I can try to elaborate more if you want but it probably won't be particularly helpful in determining what precisely is making me feel your post is genuine (and in the end, it'll probably somehow go back to gut).

Implosion is being very defensive. He obviously is hiding something. I don't believe in soft claiming. If you know something, and you are hinting at it, you should just say it.

Edo is in no danger of being lynched and Imp's defense of him came off as very strange and awkward to me.

Monkeyman + 5
Spoiler: Explanation of what the "+5" means
I rank scumtells on a scale from 0 (absolute town) to 100 (absolute scum). Each person starts at 50. The basis for the points is my own view of how serious a scumtell is (ie the numbers are not a measure of probability calculated using a formula or anything). The main point of the system is just to help me better track how people sit relative to one another over the course of a game. I try to keep things in intervals of 5, so 5 means a minor/ordinary scumtell, 10 is a serious one, etc

VOTE: Monkeyman

A few reasons for this.

1) It's not taking an accusatory tone without making a direct accusation. The point that Monkeyman was making is pretty obvious - in most circumstances, only scum would be in a position to have a declared townread of somebody on the first page (and it's safe to assume that a mason, daycop, etc wouldn't be dumb enough to declare their knowledge so prematurely). I fail to see why what he said is scummy when, on this reasoning, it would have been perfectly okay (I'll get to the "seems" thing in a second) if he'd said: "Implosion seems to know somebody is town. Only scum would know that. Therefore, Implosion is scummy."

2) As for the "seems" point, you're again being ridiculously strict. Sure, "seems" CAN be used for scummy hedging, but it is also perfectly legit to use it where you are reasonably uncertain. Two examples:
potentially scummy/hedging use of seems wrote:What Mr X just did seems scummy to me

non-scummy use of seems wrote:Mr X seems to know too much


In the first example, the person is being unclear about whether or not they think what Mr X did is scummy (ie there is a chance they are trying to hide their true position). Even this isn't necessarily scummy, since it might well be unclear.

In the second example, however, it's just stating an objective fact - Mr X does appear to know too much. The person doesn't know whether Mr X actually does know too much - so the most true thing that they can say is that Mr X "seems" (ie appears) to know too much.

3) Your "Third" isn't really a new point so much as just a melding of the two previous ones. Anyway, the same things I said above apply here also.

In post 131, Bub Bidderskins wrote:Volkan, could I get some of your meta?


My wiki page lists a lot of my past games.

Basically, my meta is:
- I tend towards hyper-logical scumhunting. By this, I'm not trying to say that I am always logical/correct. What I mean is that I loathe "gut"/intuitive reads (see my avatar). This means that in certain types of games (where there is a lot of rational debate to analyse) I tend to appear pro-town. On the other hand, where games are less analysis-heavy I seem more scummy (since if I can't prove that anybody is being wrong or inconsistent, I kind of enter a paralysis).
- I tend to get involved in lengthy back-and-forth arguments, but I am nowhere near as bad as I used to be
- My scale ranges from 0 to 100, but it's uncommon for anybody to go below 50. This is because I have trouble thinking of things as towntells. In my head, when I think: "Would I do this as scum?" , then, thinking strategically, very few things come out as towntells.

1) I'm not trying to say that I have more than one non-null read. Subject to what I say below in 2), I do only have one non-null read.
2) The point I was trying to get across in 509 was simply that "null" doesn't equal "no opinion". As in, not finding somebody's play scummy is different from not having an opinion. If this seems obvious, the reason I raise it is just that I find people often treat "null read" similarly to how they'd treat "I haven't read that player's posts"
3) Some background, in case it helps. A scum/town-tell is an action that makes it more likely that a player is scum/town. In practical application of this, my operating definition of a scumtell is: "Any action that a town player would not reasonably take in the circumstances". My operating definition of a towntell is: "Any action that a scum player would not reasonably take in the circumstances." Now, at first glance, that seems symmetrical. However, the range of actions that town could reasonably do is actually MUCH narrower than the range of actions that scum could reasonably do. The reason for this is that whereas town's sole motivation should be "catching scum", scum have at least three motivations: lynching town, self-preservation, and confusion.
